text: welcome to a demonstration of overthe a
cross platform infection for breaking
mton based online banking
authentication the video is splitted in
three parts in the first part we will
show how mton authentication Works to
avoid any trouble with real Banks we
created a bank simulator which provides
the same
functionality the second part will
explain and demonstrate how our attack
works and the last part shows our
successful attacker can now transfer
money to his
account now in order to do a transaction
the user first has to authenticate to
the bank this is normally done by
entering user ID and a
password next the user will enter the
destination and the amount of money he
likes to transfer the bank now generates
a transaction authentication number
which can be thought of as a onetime
password for the transaction and which
is only valid for a short period of time
it is important to notice that not only
the mobile tun is sent but also the
recipient and the amount of money so the
user can verify the correctness of this
transaction to complete the transaction
the user has to enter this generated
Anon the scheme is supposed to be secure
because even if the computer gets
infected by mware although it can steal
the lockin credentials can't do a
transaction because it still needs a
valid ton th for the attacker to be able
to bypass the scheme it is necessary to
take control over the mobile device
which receives the
tons this is considered as a hard
problem while this was a reasonable
assumption back in the time when mobile
devices functionality was limited to
telepone and SMS we now show that this
assumption does not apply to Modern
smartphones an attacker who has full
control over the computer can easily
infect the mobile device by means of
direct cross device
infection this can be done through any
interface like Bluetooth USB or
Wi-Fi we show the cross device infection
over Wi-Fi because many users connect
both devices to the same wireless
network for example at home at work or
in
hotels the attack itself consists of two
phases in the first phase the computer
aims to become a man in the
middle this can be achieved differently
we use the dhtp starvation attack in
combination with a rogue DHCP
server now that the infected PC
installed itself successfully as a man
in the middle it can substitute any
requested web page with a malicious one
such a malicious web page would contain
an exploit against the browser get code
execution on the mobile
device in our case the Shell Code
downloads and executes the binary from
the infected PC which contains the
malware for the mobile device and a root
exploit to start the malware with root
privileges
as you can see full control over the PC
means that the PC mare can easily steal
the Locking credentials during a normal
authentication against a bank server but
again these are useless for an attacker
if he wants to perform a more security
critical task such as transferring money
to another
account we designed this attack to be
very stealthy so to make it more
comprehensible for you we've created
some console
output for now you can can see the HTTP
post request which was captured
previously and contains the Locking
credentials for the
bank on the right side is the Target
mobile device which is about to join the
wireless network normally this will
happen automatically when the user comes
for example home from work in our case
we simulate this Behavior by simply
activating the wireless
interface as soon as the mobile device
accepted the network configuration from
our Rog HTP server you can see how all h
HTTP requests are forwarded to a local
server which runs on the infected
machine and which answers all these
requests with a page containing the
exploit so when the user eventually
opens the browser it doesn't matter to
which page he wants to browse all these
pages are substituted with a page
containing the
exploit so now it looks like the browser
is crashed in reality the exploit just
downloaded and started the mobile device
mware the mware will reset the mobile
devices Network configuration so when
the user now opens the browser again
everything will work as
expected in the meantime the mobile
device mware reported the mobile devic's
phone number to the PC mware which
reports the phone number and the
authentication credentials to an
attacker
server the attacker is now in possession
of the authentication credentials and
has full control over the mobile device
as said before the user can now browse
again to any web page without being
redirected to the infected
PC we switch now to the attacker's
workspace on the left side will be a
view on the infected mobile device in
the middle the website of our bank and
on the right side will be the server
which collects all the storing data the
attacker now uses the stor credentials
to authenticate against the bank server
and types in the destination and the
amount of money he likes to transfer as
demonstrated in the first part at this
point a mobile ton is generated and sent
to the mobile device which is associated
with this account however this time the
mar on the mobile device will intercept
the reception of the new SMS suppress it
so the user won't notice anything and
forward it to the attacker server where
it will pop up after a few seconds the
attacker finally just copies the mobile
turn to complete the
transaction in this video we
demonstrated that D cross device
infection is a feasible approach for
bypassing mton
authentication although we only
demonstrated how to use cross device
infection to break mobile ton
authentication this attack scenario
affects of course any two Factor
authentication which involves the
smartphone while the overall attack
scenario is new each involved attack
step is based on non attack techniques
such as Menin the-middle in Wi-Fi
networks remote exploitation or
privilege escalation to gain root
privileges this implies that the attack
can be implemented by a knowledgeable
attacker and is a rear threat of today's
online banking
